Module org.monarchinitiative.phenol.core
Package org.monarchinitiative.phenol.ontology.data

Interface MinimalOntology

All Superinterfaces:
Serializable, Versioned
All Known Subinterfaces:
Ontology
All Known Implementing Classes:
ImmutableOntology, SimpleMinimalOntology
public interface MinimalOntology extends Serializable, Versioned
Interface for ontologies without the all-ancestor-related convenience functions.

Most classes will want to work with Ontology instead of MinimalOntology as the more interesting algorithms on ontologies need fast access to all ancestors of a term.

Following the "composition over inheritance" paradigm, an Ontology is composed of a OntologyGraph and methods termForTermId(TermId)s relationshipById(int) for assigning TermIds and edge ids to the corresponding labels.

The graph contains one vertex for each TermId in the loaded ontology (corresponding to [TermI] stanzas in OBO). Terms that are just referred to are not represented in the ontology.

While MinimalOntology allows access to TermIds of obsolete Terms in the ontology, the obsolete Terms are excluded from the underlying graph structure.

Terms vs. Term IDs
OBO files contain lists of terms (besides other entry types). Each term has one primary identifier and a (possibly empty) list of alternative IDs. Terms can also be marked as obsolete. While appearing simple on the surface, this has several implications for this interface:
  • The Term-returning function termForTermId(TermId) performs a mapping from TermId to the corresponding Term, regardless of whether the key value is a primary or an alternative identifier.
  • The Iterable-returning functions nonObsoleteTermIds(), obsoleteTermIds(), and allTermIds() return the primary term identifiers for non-obsolete, obsolete, and all term IDs.
Iterating
For iterating over terms and term IDs only use the functions getTerms(), nonObsoleteTermIds(), obsoleteTermIds(), and getTerms(). These functions return iterables with elements from this ontology.
Ontology hierarchy

MinimalOntology provides an OntologyGraph which in turn supports traversals of the ontology hierarchy.

Invariants/Properties
  • MinimalOntology instances have one root term (non-obsolete, having no incoming "is-a" relations), thus the graph is connected.
  • The underlying OntologyGraph is acyclic and simple (no two equal directed s-t edges).
Author:
Manuel Holtgrewe, Sebastian Koehler, Peter Robinson, Daniel Danis
